stem: Differentiate between left-sided and right-sided heart failure clinical cues.
template: The nurse identifies {{sign1}} as a classic sign of left-sided heart failure due to pulmonary congestion, while {{sign2}} is indicative of right-sided heart failure causing systemic venous congestion.

rationale.correct: Left-sided heart failure (HF) occurs when the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the systemic circulation. This leads to a backup of blood into the pulmonary vasculature, increasing pulmonary hydrostatic pressure. This increased pressure forces fluid into the alveoli, causing pulmonary edema and manifesting as crackles and dyspnea. Right-sided HF occurs when the right ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the pulmonary circulation. This causes a backup of blood into the systemic venous system, increasing systemic venous pressure. This increased pressure leads to fluid accumulation in the tissues, resulting in jugular venous distension (JVD).
rationale.incorrect: Pink frothy sputum is a sign of acute pulmonary edema, a severe complication of left-sided heart failure, but JVD is primarily associated with right-sided heart failure due to systemic venous congestion. Peripheral edema, ascites, and splenomegaly are also associated with right-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: The most common cause of right-sided heart failure is left-sided heart failure. Managing fluid volume and sodium intake are crucial in both types of heart failure.

SBAR: Situation: Patient experiencing signs of heart failure. Background: History of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Assessment: Crackles in bilateral lung bases, JVD present, peripheral edema +2. Vital signs: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 24 breaths/min, SpO2 90% on room air. Recommendation: Administer oxygen, elevate head of bed, administer diuretic as prescribed, and monitor vital signs closely. Notify provider of changes in condition. Time: 1400.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the signs and symptoms of left-sided and right-sided heart failure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the mnemonic 'L' for Left/Lung to associate pulmonary symptoms with left-sided heart failure, and think of right-sided heart failure as affecting the 'Rest' of the body, causing systemic symptoms.

answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "Crackles/Dyspnea" correctly identifies a key clinical manifestation of left-sided heart failure, resulting from pulmonary congestion.

mnemonic.title: FORWARD (Heart Failure)
mnemonic.expansion: Fatigue, Orthopnea, Weight gain, Ascites, Restlessness, Distended neck veins (JVD)

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Heart Failure Pathophysiology
reviewUnits.body: Review the Frank-Starling mechanism, neurohormonal responses (RAAS, SNS), and structural changes (remodeling) in heart failure. Understand the differences between systolic and diastolic heart failure.

reviewUnits.heading: Medication Management of Heart Failure
reviewUnits.body: Study the mechanisms of action, side effects, and nursing considerations for diuretics, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta-blockers, and digoxin in the management of heart failure.
